case_name: Mirza Ali Akbar Kashani v. United Arab Republic

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 220 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 220 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 17, 1961 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 115 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 17, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 11

facts.text: Suit filed by appellant Mirza Ali Akbar Kashani against United Arab Republic and Ministry of Economy, Supplies, Importation Department of Republic of Egypt at Cairo on Original Side of Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit filed by the appellant, Mirza Ali Akbar Kashani, against the two respondents, the United Arab Republic, and the Ministry of Economy, Supplies, Importation Depa

facts.text: Appellant claimed damages of Rs. 6,07,346 for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: By his plaint, the appellant claimed to recover from the respondents damages assessed at Rs. 6,07,346 for breach of contract.

facts.text: Contract made between parties on March 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, the contract in question was made between the parties on March 27, 1958.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 agreed to buy tea from appellant exclusively during tenure of contract and give first refusal for additional requirements.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 which was a party to the contract had agreed to buy tea from the appellant upon certain terms and conditions one of these was that respondent No. 2 would not place any further orders

facts.text: Respondents placed order for tea with third party without giving appellant chance to comply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that during the tenure of the contract, the respondents had wrongfully placed an order for the supply of tea with a third party without giving the appellant a chance to comply

facts.text: Republic of Egypt and Republic of Syria merged to form United Arab Republic on February 22, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Formerly, the Republic of Egypt and the Republic of Syria were two independent sovereign States. They, however, merged and formed a new Sovereign State on February 22, 1958.

facts.text: United Arab Republic recognized by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: This new sovereign State is known as the United Arab Republic and is referred as respondent No. 1 in the present appeal. This new State has been recognised by the Government of India.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 is a department of Respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 has been working as a department of respondent No. 1 and is a part and parcel thereof.

facts.text: Suit instituted on August 10, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit was instituted on August 10, 1959.

facts.text: Appellant did not obtain consent of Central Government under s. 86 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the appellant did not obtain the consent of the Central Government to the institution of the suit under s. 86 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Leave under Clause 12 Letters Patent granted by trial Judge as part of cause of action arose in jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, applied for leave under Clause 12 of the Letters Patent in view of the fact that a part of the cause of action had arisen within the jurisdiction of the Calcutta High Court. This leave was granted

facts.text: Respondents entered appearance on December 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On December 3, 1959, the respondents entered appearance in the suit

facts.text: Respondents applied on December 17, 1959 to revoke leave, reject plaint, stay proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: and on December 17, 1959, they applied for an order that the leave granted under Clause 12 of the Letters Patent should be revoked, the plaint should be rejected and further proceedings in the suit should be stayed.

facts.text: Trial Judge held s.86 does not bar suit, rejected immunity plea, no waiver, dismissed application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Judge held that s. 86 did not bar the present suit. ... In the result, the application made by the respondents for revoking leave was dismissed by the trial Judge.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Division Bench upheld no bar under s.86, but allowed appeal on immunity and waiver, rejected plaint.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned Judges who constituted the Court of Appeal have upheld the finding of the trial Judge that s. 86 of the Code does not create a bar against the present suit. They have, however, reversed the trial Judges conclusions on the question of immunity ... the plaint filed by the appellant has been rejected

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate from Court of Appeal for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has applied for and obtained a certificate from the Court of Appeal and it is with the said certificate that he has come to this Court in appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.86 bars the suit without Central Government consent.

anchor.surface_text: we have come to the conclusion that the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court were, with respect, in error in holding that s. 86 does not create a bar against the present suit.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed as suit barred under s.86 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: No part of cause of action alleged to have arisen within jurisdiction according to respondents.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents, the trial Court had no jurisdiction ... It was further averred on their behalf that no part of the alleged cause of action had arisen within the jurisdiction of the Court

facts.text: Suit against President of United Arab Republic as Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as the President of the United Arab Republic was its Ruler and the suit was, in reality, and in substance, a suit against him and as such, it was barred under S. 86 of the Code.

facts.text: Transaction not related to governmental functions.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also urged that in view of the fact that the transaction which has given rise to the present suit has nothing to do with the governmental functions of respondent No. 1, no immunity could be claimed

facts.text: Respondents submitted to jurisdiction by appearance and pleas.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant further contended that by appearing in the present proceedings and by filing pleas thereafter, the respondents had submitted to the jurisdiction of the Court and had waived their objection
It is common ground that the appellant did not obtain the consent of the Central Government to the institution of the suit under s. 86 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: Whether s. 86 of the Code of Civil Procedure bars the present suit

anchor.surface_text: During the course of the hearing of this appeal, it thus became clear that two questions fall to be considered by us the first is in relation to the application of s. 86 of the Code and the second

anchor.surface_text: in relation to the application of s. 86 of the Code and the second in regard to the scope and effect of the doctrine of immunity under International Law. Logically, the effect of s. 86 has to be considered first,

issues.text: Was the Calcutta High Court right in holding that the present suit does not fall under the purview of s. 86(1)?

anchor.surface_text: The point which arises for our decision thus lies within a narrow compass was the Calcutta High Court right in holding that the present suit does not fall under the purview of s. 86 1 ?

arguments.claim: Suit against foreign State in its name is suit against Ruler per s.87

anchor.surface_text: Section 87 provides that the Ruler of a foreign State may sue, and shall be sued, in the name of his State.

arguments.claim: Ruler includes head of republican State per s.87A definition

anchor.surface_text: Section 87A (1) which has been added... prescribes the definitions of foreign State and Ruler. Section 87A 1 a provides that... foreign State means any State outside India which has been recognised by the Central Government and b Ruler... the person who is for the time being recognised... head of that State.

arguments.claim: Provisions read harmoniously: s.84 allows State to sue private rights, s.86 limits liability to be sued

anchor.surface_text: In this connection, it is necessary to bear in mind that even when the Ruler of a State sues or is sued, the suit has to be in the name of the State that is the effect of the provision of S. 87, so that it may be legitimate to infer that the effect of reading sections 84, 86 and 87 together is that a suit would be in the name of the State

arguments.claim: s.86 modifies International Law immunity; statute governs over common law

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the provisions of s. 86 (1) appears to be that it makes a statutory provision covering a field which would otherwise be covered by the doctrine of immunity under International Law.

holdings.text: The learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court were in error in holding that s. 86 does not create a bar against the present suit.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing both Mir. Chaudhry and Mr. Sen, we have come to the conclusion that the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court were, with respect, in error in holding that s. 86 does not create a bar against the present suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 84, 86, 87 and 87A read together show that a suit against a foreign State in the name of the State is a suit against its Ruler requiring Central Government consent; applies to republics via s.87A definition.

holdings.text: Section 86(1) applies to suits against Rulers of foreign States and foreign States fall within its scope whatever be their form of Government.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that s. 86 1  applies to cases where suits are brought against Rulers of foreign States and that foreign States fall within its scope whatever be their form of Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of ss.84 (State sues for private rights), 86 (Ruler sued with consent), 87 (sued in name of State), 87A (Ruler=recognized head); no distinction between monarchies and republics.

holdings.text: Ruler of a foreign State includes the person recognised by Central Government as head of that State, regardless of republican or monarchical form.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the definition prescribed by s. 8 7A  1   b , it seems difficult to accept the argument that the expression the Ruler of a foreign State under s. 86 1  can take in cases only of Rulers of foreign States which are governed by a monarchical form of Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of s.87A(1)(b) definition applies to all recognized heads of foreign States; 1951 amendment aware of republics.

holdings.text: The Ruler of a foreign State may sue, and shall be sued, in the name of his State; thus suit against State is against Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: Section 87 provides that the Ruler of a foreign State may sue, and shall be sued, in the name of his State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.87 procedural rule harmonized with ss.84 and 86.

holdings.text: Section 86(1) makes a statutory provision covering the field of immunity from suit which would otherwise be covered by the doctrine of immunity under International Law.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the provisions of s. 86 (1) appears to be that it makes a statutory provision covering a field which would otherwise be covered by the doctrine of immunity under International Law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute modifies common law/international law immunity; municipal courts bound by CPC provisions over general doctrines when specific statute applies.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider the plea of absolute immunity under International Law as s.86 governs the competence of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: That being our view, we do number propose to companysider whether the Court of Appeal was right in  1  1959 A.C. 379. upholding the respondents plea of absolute immunity under International Law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific statutory provision in s.86 determines suit's competence; no need to resort to international law if statute applies.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit barred under s.86 without consent; High Court order upheld on this ground.

precedents.cited_proposition: denotation of the words 'private rights' spoken of in s. 431, clause (b) of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1882
precedents.cited_holding: the said words do number mean individual rights as opposed to those of the body politic or State, but those private rights of the State which must be enforced in a Court of Justice, as distinguished from its political or territorial rights

precedents.citation: Chandulal Khushalji v. Awed Ritz Umar Sultan Nawaz Jung Bahadur 1 I.L.R.21 Bom. 351

anchor.surface_text: Chandulal Khushalji v. Awed Ritz Umar Sultan Nawaz Jung Bahadur 1

precedents.case_name: Chandulal Khushalji v. Awed Ritz Umar Sultan Nawaz Jung Bahadur
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 433 of the Code of 1882 creates a personal privilege for sovereign princes and ruling chiefs which is a modified form of the absolute privilege enjoyed by independent sovereigns
precedents.cited_holding: It is a modified form of the absolute privilege enjoyed by independent sovereigns and their ambassadors in the Courts in England, in accordance with the principles of international law. The difference is that while in England the privilege is unconditional... in India it is dependent upon the companysent of the Governor General in Council

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed as the suit is barred under s. 86(1) of the Code of Civil Procedure in the absence of the consent of the Central Government.
